abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment summary
            for the Cameroon Railway Concessioning Project identifies
            the principal negative social and environmental impacts of
            the current railroad operations and the project, and
            recommends simple and cost effective measures to avoid or
            mitigate the adverse impacts. The most adverse activities
            are: the application of creosote, a toxic preservative, to
            railroad sleepers in the Cameroon Railway (CR) workshops;
            the inadequate surveillance of the tracks; the rental of
            land and shops in the right of way; three issues related to
            the management of the railway and CR facilities, also the
            management and maintenance of CR rolling stock; and finally,
            the illegal transportation of bush meat and rainforest logs,
            and the transportation of hazardous materials. Some of the
            key mitigation measures include installing a treatment
            system that limits creosote pollution, evaluating creosote
            treatment sites, informing the public of contamination risk,
            using protective clothing, collaborating with the population
            living near the track to reinforce informal surveillance,
            financing an inventory of the right of way in order to
            define responsibilities and establish a sound land
            management system, improving waste management of the CR land
            area, building security fencing, improving the management
            and handling of oil and diesel fuels, and controlling the
            transport of bush meat, rainforest logs, and hazardous materials.
